intro: Pleomele cincta, commonly known as the orange-fig cycad, is a member of the Cycadaceae family and is native to Madagascar. It is a slow-growing, evergreen plant characterized by its stout, unbranched trunk and a crown of feathery, pinnate leaves. The leaves are typically a deep green with a reddish or orange tint along the midrib, giving it its common name. It produces small, inconspicuous flowers that develop into hard, woody fruits containing edible seeds. Due to its ornamental value and conservation status, it is often cultivated in botanical gardens and private collections.
